Traffic counts at Bay Area bridges have been roughly 70% lower in recent days than normal, Martien said.
And carbon dioxide, a leading greenhouse gas, is off roughly 20% due to the decline in Bay Area driving, Martien said.

The Evergreen School District in San Jose is moving forward with a plan to close two elementary schools at the end of this school year, according to a district release Wednesday.
District Superintendent Emy Flores announced she will be recommending to the Board of Trustees the closure/consolidation of Laurelwood and Dove Hill elementary schools.
"This is a difficult recommendation to make because none of us want to have to close schools," Flores said in a statement.

In San Jose, marchers streamed into the City Hall rotunda, bundled up in thick scarves and carrying signs reading “Trump is a cyberbully” and “I’m with her” with a finger pointing to Mother Earth.

SAN JOSE (KRON) – Authorities said one person has been arrested following a stabbing in San JoseIt happened overnight near the area of Wyman Way and Gilchrist Drive.
According to officials, one person was stabbed and suffered non-life threatening injuries.
At this time there does not appear to be any other suspects involved, authorities said.
No other details were immediately available.

title: Girl uses Snapchat to escape kidnappers in San Jose
summary:
SAN JOSE (KRON) – Police have arrested three men accused of kidnapping and sexually assaulting a 14-year-old girl.
Investigators say on Tuesday the three suspects – later identified as Albert Vasquez, Antonio Salvador, and Hediberto Avarenga – approached the victim in Capitola and drugged her.
They then took her to an EZ-8 Motel in San Jose where they attacked her and sexually assaulted her.
Police say the girl used Snapchat to alert her friends about what was going on.
“With social media too if you don’t have a phone line to call somebody it’s really easy for social media to contact somebody and give them all the information they need to know,” said motel guest Angie Pueblas.

title: San Jose flight headed to San Diego returns due to mechanical issue
summary:
SAN JOSE (KRON) — A flight from the Bay Area to Southern California had to quickly turn around to a mechanical issue.
After departing at 4:53 p.m. on Sunday, a caution light turned on in the cockpit which indicated a faulty sensor had been found.
The captain of Alaska SkyWest flight 3467 decided to return to San Jose to have maintenance inspect the aircraft.
San Jose International Airport originally reported that a door had opened, but a spokesperson with Alaska Airlines later determined there was no issue with the aircraft door.
The plane returned safely to San Jose at 5:35 p.m. and no injuries were reported.

title: Parents Want Cellphone Tower Taken Off Church Steeple in San Jose
summary:
A battle in the South Bay involving new technology and health concerns has taken an unusual religious twist.
Some parents and parishioners are taking the Catholic Diocese of San Jose to task for a cellphone tower on the church steeple at St. Christopher Catholic Church, which is also home to a school.
"Until the evidence is established that cell tower radiation isn't harmful for our children, cell towers like the one at the church steeple at St. Chris should be removed," parent John Conway said.
The diocese started leasing space on the steeple to a cellular company back in 1999.
In a statement, the diocese said the health and safety of parents, children and parishioners are its top priority.

title: California Real Estate Markets Make a Comeback in January, but Affordability Is Still Key Nationwide
summary:
As we look back on the first month of 2020, it seems that the new year has indeed brought changes to the real estate market.
An analysis of realtor.com® data for January shows that California markets are again buzzing with real estate activity, even as affordability continues to be a driving factor across the country.
California markets made up 10 of the top 20 metros in realtor.com's monthly list of the hottest real estate markets in America.
So January's top 20 is a reversal of this recent trend of California markets cooling off, notes realtor.com Chief Economist Danielle Hale.
Check out the rest of the metros where real estate activity is hopping, below—but if you're thinking of buying, you might not want to wait.

title: Hyatt House opens at California’s San Jose airport – Business Traveller
summary:
Hyatt has opened the 100th hotel under its Hyatt House brand, with a new-build property located next to Norman Y Mineta San Jose International airport.
Hyatt House San Jose airport features free wifi and daily “Morning Spread” hot buffet breakfast, as well as a fitness centre, The Commons lobby lounge, Outdoor Commons with fire pit and BBQ grill, H Bar, 24-hour H Market grab-and-go shop, and 1,800 square feet of meeting and events space.
To celebrate the opening, the World of Hyatt loyalty programme is offering 500 bonus points for stays at the Hyatt House San Jose airport until March 31 – for more information visit worldofhyatt.com/newhotelbonus.
Commenting on the news, the hotel’s general manager John McEntee said:“We are thrilled to be the Hyatt House brand’s one hundredth hotel and to bring a new and dynamic guest experience to the San Jose marketplace for both business and personal occasion travellers.
“With more than 15 million passengers traveling through SJC in 2019, we’re confident Hyatt House San Jose Airport will provide guests with a comfortable stay experience before embarking on the next leg of their journey.”This week Hyatt also officially opened the Hyatt House Manchester Oxford Road, a rebranding of the existing Staybridge Suites Manchester Oxford Road.

title: Apartment Fire Displaces 9, Burns 4 Units in Campbell
summary:
An apartment fire displaced nine residents Monday evening in Campbell, a spokesperson for the Santa Clara County Fire Department said.
Firefighters from San Jose and Santa Clara County were dispatched at about 6:50 p.m. to an apartment fire in the 1000 block of West Hamilton Avenue, spokesperson Luisa Rapport said.
Crews arrived to find a second-floor apartment engulfed in flames with fire spreading to three more units.
Four units sustained fire damage, Rapport said.
The cause of the fire is under investigation, but initial information indicates it likely originated in the kitchen as someone was cooking.

title: California and Coronavirus: Eight Cases Are Confirmed in the State
summary:
SAN FRANCISCO — The seventh and eighth cases of coronavirus in California were confirmed this week in people who had been evacuated from Wuhan, China, to the United States.

Four of the state’s cases are in Southern California and four in the San Francisco Bay Area.

title: Despite budget shortfall, San Jose spends $17 million on tiny homes for homeless amid the coronavirus outbreak
authors: Maggie Angst Covers Government On The Peninsula For The Mercury News. She'S A Chicago Native
Previously Covered Breaking News For The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
Education For The Island Packet In Hilton Head
summary:
With thousands of San Jose residents on the streets with no safe place to ride out the mounting coronavirus pandemic, city leaders are fast-tracking a $17 million plan to build hundreds of tiny homes for the homeless population.
Gavin Newsom last month, the city anticipates that the $17 million will allow the city build up to 500 modular and pre-fabricated homes on public and private property for homeless residents.
The city opened its first community of 40 tiny homes in February on a Valley Transportation Authority site leased by the city on Mabury Road near Coyote Creek.
City leaders voted to allocate the $17 million toward the tiny homes project despite its latest projection that it anticipates a $110 million shortfall in its budget over the next two fiscal years.
“Our need for housing our homeless neighbors, not to mention our neighbors in overcrowded housing, has never been greater,” Councilmember Dev Davis said.

title: Coronavirus: Bay Area air quality is improving as people stay home
authors: Paul Rogers Has Covered A Wide Range Of Issues For The Mercury News Since
summary:
When we look at our measurements, it is below what we were seeing a few weeks ago, for sure,” said Phil Martien, director of assessment, inventory and modeling at the Bay Area Air Quality Management District in San Francisco.
Traffic counts at Bay Area bridges have been roughly 70% lower in recent days than normal, Martien said.
And carbon dioxide, a leading greenhouse gas, is off roughly 20% due to the decline in Bay Area driving, Martien said.
“This is not how we want to see air quality go down,” Martien said.
Most months, Bay Area air quality is generally cleaner than in many parts of the world, including in Los Angeles and the Central Valley.

title: The federal fraud trial of former Theranos CEO Elizabeth Holmes will be delayed until October due to the pandemic
summary:
The federal judge presiding over the criminal trial of Elizabeth Holmes, ex-CEO of Theranos, has ruled that proceedings will be delayed until October.
Federal prosecutors intend to pursue adding further charges of fraud and conspiracy to commit fraud to Holmes' indictment after some charges were dismissed in February.
The trial for Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of failed blood-testing startup Theranos facing federal fraud charges, has been delayed until October due to the coronavirus outbreak.
The federal judge presiding over the case, Edward Davila, said during a hearing Wednesday that the original trial start date set for July was no longer "realistic."
The federal court in San Jose, California, where Holmes' trial is supposed to take place, is closed until at least May 1.

SAN JOSE – A man sought by police in a deadly shooting in the East San Jose hills last month was arrested Thursday, after barricading himself in a stranger’s home and stalemating police for hours before he was flushed out with tear gas and a police dog, authorities said.
Marcus Sloan Pardohenry, 33, of San Jose, was arrested around 3 a.m. at the home on Vista Verde Drive between Tully Road and San Rivas Drive, according to San Jose police.
Pardohenry was the second suspect arrested this week in connection with the Jan. 15 shooting death of 26-year-old Richard Huy Nguyen near Clayton Road and Squeri Drive.
On Tuesday, the San Jose Police Department’s covert response unit arrested 28-year-old Richard Alexis Torres in Santa Clara.
Police said officers fired two beanbag rounds at the suspect, and sent a police dog after him to subdue and arrest him.

title: California Drought: Northern California having driest February since 1864
authors: Paul Rogers Has Covered A Wide Range Of Issues For The Mercury News Since
summary:
Another 46.4% of California is now classified as “abnormally dry.”Sunny, dry weather, with temperatures in the 60s and 70s, is forecast for at least another week across Northern California.
The culprit for the dry weather?
The closely-watched weather stations are located in watersheds from Mount Shasta to south of Lake Tahoe that empty into the major reservoirs of Northern California.
And the lack of rain this February has been historic across Northern California.
Because of reservoir and groundwater storage, it typically takes at least two years of dry winters for a major drought to emerge in California.

title: San Jose residents upset to find out drinking water was contaminated
summary:
SAN JOSE, Calif. (KRON) – Some Willow Glen residents upset to find out their drinking water may have had higher than normal levels of a sulfonic acid.
More than just learning about this substance potentially being in their water, some people say what makes them most upset at San Jose Water is that they weren’t notified of the issue until months after it was discovered.
This is just one of about 11,000 San Jose Water customers who received a notice from the water company warning of potential per-fluoro-octane sulfonic acid concentrations above the state notification level in their drinking water.
The substance, also known as PFOs, is described by San Jose Water as a man-made substance that has been synthesized for water and fat resistance and used in products like carpets clothing and cookware.
The origin of the contaminant is unknown, according to San Jose Water, but they say they are working to determine how it was introduced into the groundwater supply.

title: Crime Drops Around the World as COVID-19 Keeps People Inside
summary:

Still, law enforcement officials worry about a surge of unreported domestic violence, and what happens when restrictions lift — or go on too long.
It’s rare for a city to see a double-digit drop in crime, even over a much longer period.
During New York City’s 1990s crime decline, one of the biggest turnarounds in American history, crime dropped about 40% over three years.
That makes the drop-offs occurring now — in a period of just a couple of weeks — even more seismic.

title: Two San Jose Elementary Schools Set to Close at End of 2019-2020
summary:
The Evergreen School District in San Jose is moving forward with a plan to close two elementary schools at the end of this school year, according to a district release Wednesday.
District Superintendent Emy Flores announced she will be recommending to the Board of Trustees the closure/consolidation of Laurelwood and Dove Hill elementary schools.
"This is a difficult recommendation to make because none of us want to have to close schools," Flores said in a statement.
The Board of Trustees public hearings will be held Monday, Jan. 27 and Monday, Feb. 3 at 6 p.m. at Quimby Oak Middle School gymnasium, 3190 Quimby Road in San Jose.

title: Santa Clara County’s homeless prevention program is only serving a third of those seeking help
authors: Maggie Angst Covers Government On The Peninsula For The Mercury News. She'S A Chicago Native

summary:
Since launching in 2017, the countywide Homelessness Prevention System has offered 1,338 families at risk of losing their housing with emergency financial assistance, such as money to cover rent, moving costs or mediation with a landlord.
But the countywide system has only been able to serve about a third of people who have sought assistance through the program.
Simply put, the program needs more funding to make a dent in the county’s homeless problem, said Loving, whose organization is one of 15 tasked with administering the program.
The county’s homeless prevention system has received $28 million from a combination of public and private funding sources, including the state, county, cities of San Jose, Santa Clara and Morgan Hill and tech companies such as Apple, Cisco and Google.
Mayor Sam Liccardo, the most vocal proponent of the proposed transfer tax, says the tax would allow the city to more than double its current contribution to the homeless prevention program.

title: Earthquake risk prompts order to drain Calif. dam
summary:
They ordered its reservoir to be completely drained by October 2020, due to concerns that the dam could send floodwaters into communities.
Retrofit plans have been in the works for years and the dam’s water level has been kept at a maximum of 74% since 2009.
SAN JOSE, Calif. (AP) — Worried that an earthquake could collapse a big dam south of San Francisco, officials have ordered its reservoir to be completely drained by October to reduce the risk of floodwaters spilling into Silicon Valley.
Since 2009, the dam’s water level has been kept at a maximum of 74 percent of capacity because of an assessment that it could fail in a 7.2 quake.
Coyote Creek flows from the dam through downtown San Jose to San Francisco Bay.

summary:
SAN FRANCISCO – A number of Bay Area community colleges and one K-12 school system are moving in-person classes online amid the novel coronavirus outbreak.
On Tuesday, the San Francisco Archdiocesan said all 90 of its schools will close for two weeks, starting Thursday.
The move follows confirmation by the San Francisco Public Health Department on Sunday that a student had tested positive for COVID-19.
In the South Bay, three community colleges – San Jose City, Evergreen Valley and Mission – joined a growing list of other major universities in suspending in-person classes.
Classes will resume online or through distance learning beginning Monday at San Jose City and Evergreen Valley colleges in San Jose and beginning April 6 at Mission College in Santa Clara.

title: Finally, rain! Here’s when the Bay Area will get wet
authors: Paul Rogers Has Covered A Wide Range Of Issues For The Mercury News Since
summary:
After a historically dry February, the Bay Area is about to see a surprising — and sorely needed — change of pace: rain!
A cold front will deliver moisture from the Gulf of Alaska and light showers shortly after midnight Friday until about 10 a.m. or 11 a.m. across much of the Bay Area.
Rain totals will be about a tenth of an inch across most Bay Area cities, said Anna Schneider, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service in Monterey.
Cold air also could mean a dusting of snow Saturday on Mount Hamilton and the other highest peaks around the Bay Area and Big Sur.
The rain will end a historic dry streak in the Bay Area.

“We’re very supportive of the mandate by the County’s Public Health Department,” said Earthquakes COO Jared Shawlee in a statement.

Special teams flopSan Diego State’s 95-yard kickoff return for a touchdown to open the game foreshadowed a very poor night in the special teams category for San Jose State.
While the Spartans failed to place San Diego State inside its own 10 on six punts over the course of the game, Aztecs punter Brandon Heicklen pinned San Jose State inside the 2-yard line three times.
But in the first half against the Aztecs, it was San Jose State’s defensive line that controlled the line of scrimmage.

Police set up a perimeter and asked the public to avoid the area.
No injuries were immediately reported.

title: San Jose without PG&E? Mayor wants to explore city-owned utilities
authors: Maggie Angst Covers Government On The Peninsula For The Mercury News. She'S A Chicago Native

summary:
One week after California’s biggest utility cut power to hundreds of thousands of residents, Mayor Sam Liccardo says he wants to explore a San Jose without Pacific Gas and Electric.
“…It’s time to explore a San Jose without PG&E.”The mayor’s memo places San Jose among a growing movement of cities and entities across the country looking for alternatives to investor-owned utilities in the face of increasing outages and frustration with unpredictable grids.
For example, San Francisco recently offered $2.5 billion to PG&E to buy its local power lines.
Other suggested measures he’s interested in pursuing include identifying reimbursement funds for taxpayers affected during shutdowns and exploring how San Jose Clean Energy can help homeowners get off the grid during a blackout.
Earlier this year, San Jose switched electricity suppliers from PG&E to San José Clean Energy — a nonprofit, locally-controlled utility known as a community choice energy program that provides residents and businesses with carbon-free electricity.

title: Curfew, Emergency Declared in California Due to Wildfire Threat; Power Shut Off for 500,000
summary:
PG&E power lines have been blamed for several high profile fires in recent years.
Power is being shut off to nearly 800,000 Pacific Gas & Electric customers in Northern California due to the threat of wildfires, and in some areas, officials declared emergencies and curfews to deal with the blackouts.
Windy conditions can cause power lines to spark fires when they are blown down, or to come into contact with trees or other vegetation.
PG&E power lines have been blamed for several high profile fires in recent years, including the blaze that killed 86 people last year in Paradise, California.
PG & E, which announced the deliberate outage, is working to prevent a repeat of a catastrophe last November in which faulty power lines it owned were determined to have sparked California's deadliest wildfire in modern history.

The Berryessa Union School District plans to use the additional funding to modernize aging school facilities, upgrade classroom technology and improve school safety and security measures.
The elementary school district plans to use the funds to help attract and retain teachers, offer competitive staff salaries and sustain strong academic programs.

Spends Most Of His Time Covering Crime
Public Safety. A Graduate Of Uc Santa Barbara
He Cut His Teeth At The Inland Valley Daily Bulletin
Has Been With The Bay Area News Group Since Its Inception.
summary:
SAN JOSE – A San Jose mother said her missing 14-year-old daughter was found safely.
The girl left for Yerba Buena High School on Friday but never returned home, her mother wrote in a Facebook post Monday.
“We have contacted the police and notified her school and still no news of her whereabouts,” the girl’s mother wrote.
“We have contacted her friends and social media but still no clue.”Late Monday night, the mother posted another Facebook update noting that police had found her daughter safe.
San Jose police listed the girl as a runaway, not a missing person, according to Officer Gina Tepoorten.

summary:
SAN JOSE – A man found dead near a freeway onramp in San Jose earlier this week has been identified by the Santa Clara County Medical Examiner-Coroner’s Office as 28-year-old transient William Andrew Arnbrister.
Arnbrister’s body was discovered in some bushes a dozen feet or so south of the First Street onramp to southbound Interstate 280 about 6:40 p.m. Tuesday, according to the California Highway Patrol.
The CHP has yet to release any additional information about the case, but the coroner’s office on Thursday confirmed it is currently being investigated as a homicide.

title: Suspect Arrested in Fatal San Jose Oct. 19 Shooting
summary:
A suspect in a fatal shooting Oct. 19 in San Jose has been arrested, police said Sunday.
Homicide detectives identified Mahad Aweis Osman, a 20-year-old San Diego resident, as the suspect in the shooting of San Francisco resident Savion Hollingsworth, 21, in the 500 block of South 10th Street in San Jose.
Officers found Hollingworth suffering from at least one gunshot just after 2 a.m. Hollingsworth was taken to a local hospital, where he died shortly after.
An arrest warrant was obtained for Osman, who was taken into custody Oct. 23 by the San Diego Police Department.
Osman was extradited to San Jose on Wendesday and booked into Santa Clara County Jail for murder, police said.

title: Home Security Cameras Capture Daytime Burglary in San Jose
summary:
A network of neighborhood home security cameras is providing helpful information to San Jose detectives investigating a mid-morning home burglary that happened last week.
The video is shocking because of how forceful the two burglars were while breaking into the home in San Jose’s Ruskin neighborhood.
On the victim’s home security camera the burglars can be seen – and heard -- making multiple attempts to kick down the door.

title: Massive California power outages may begin early Wednesday
summary:
(CNN) Two California utilities said they may cut power to more than 900,000 customers for days starting after midnight Wednesday morning because of dry winds that could down power lines and cause fires.
Southern California Edison said it's considering cutting power to more than 100,000 customers in eight counties.
The utilities haven't said how many people the outages will affect in all.
A map from PG&E shows the areas where power may be cut.
"Given the prolonged period during which the wind event will unfold, and the large number of power line miles that will need to be inspected before restoration, customers are being asked to prepare for an extended outage," PG&E said in a release.

title: Santa Clara County Employees Enter 5th Day Of Strike
summary:
SAN JOSE (CBS SF) – Santa Clara County workers will continue striking Monday morning, entering the fifth day of the strike over what workers say are unfair labor practices.
Starting at 8 a.m., workers from seven sites within the county’s Social Services Agency will walk off the job at 1867 Senter Road in San Jose, officials with Service Employees International Union local 521 said.
“We are proud to join the thousands of county workers who were on the line last week in protest of the county’s unfair labor practices that hurt our ability to reach an agreement,” Griselda Galindo, an eligibility worker, said in a statement.
“Our residents should know that there is a widespread staffing crisis across our county departments impacting our ability to provide adequate service—our workloads are unattainable and we cannot hire and retain staff.
Chris Libera, a member of SEIU Local 521 and a strike leader called the charge “baseless.”© Copyright 2019 CBS Broadcasting Inc. and Bay City News Service.

title: Coronavirus: COVID-19 may have been spreading in Bay Area since late 2019, according to report
summary:

Dr. Smith also said early detection of the virus lagged because of the severe flu season we were already having in the Bay Area and the overlap in symptoms with coronavirus.

title: US intelligence agencies started tracking coronavirus outbreak in China as early as November
summary:
US spy agencies were tracking the rise of the novel coronavirus as early as November, weeks before that information was included in President Donald Trump’s daily intelligence briefing, a former US military official told CNN.
“As a matter of practice the National Center for Medical Intelligence does not comment publicly on specific intelligence matters.
No such NCMI product exists,” Colonel Dr. R. Shane Day, director of the National Center for Medical Intelligence, said.
Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff John Hyten seemed to push back on reports that the US intelligence community was aware of the coronavirus in November, saying Thursday that the first intelligence reports he saw were in January.
Intelligence officials are also trying to determine how many cases and deaths have occurred in countries like China, where US officials say the publicly reported numbers cannot be trusted.

title: San Jose wants to use a new property transfer tax to fund affordable housing, homeless services
authors: Maggie Angst Covers Government On The Peninsula For The Mercury News. She'S A Chicago Native
Previously Covered Breaking News For The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel
Education For The Island Packet In Hilton Head
summary:
With an overwhelming lack of affordable housing and homeless services in the region, San Jose is considering asking voters to support a new real estate tax on the most expensive properties in the city to address the crisis.
The tax would vary based on a property’s transfer value — $3.75 per $500 for $2-$5 million properties, $5 per $500 for $5-$10 million properties and $7.50 per $500 for properties worth more than $10 million.
The city estimates it would generate about $70 million annually that would be used to help build more affordable housing units and provide additional services and programs for the city’s thousands of homeless residents.
City staff researched three options for raising additional funding for affordable housing and homelessness efforts — a property tax solely on commercial properties, a tax on vacant properties and a real estate transfer tax.
As the city’s homeless population continues to grow, the need for affordable housing is hard to ignore.

title: California Mayors Back Plan to Make PG&E a Cooperative
summary:
Frustrated with wildfires and intentional blackouts caused by Pacific Gas & Electric, more than two dozen California mayors and county leaders are calling for a customer-owned power company to replace the giant utility.
In a letter delivered Tuesday to the California Public Utilities Commission, the local officials embraced a proposal by Mayor Sam Liccardo of San Jose to create a cooperative that would use their collective resources to take over the utility.
PG&E, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January after accumulating an estimated $30 billion in liabilities from wildfires caused by its equipment, is widely expected to emerge with a different structure.
Any bankruptcy plan requiring a rate increase is subject to approval by the utilities commission.
“The commission must do more than approve a plan — any plan — merely so that the bankruptcy can be concluded,” the government officials stated in the letter.

title: Police: Man armed with gun barricaded inside home in San Jose
summary:
SAN JOSE (KRON) — Police in San Jose are working to convince a man armed with a gun to come out of a home Monday night after he allegedly barricaded himself inside.
Police say officers responded to a home on South 8th Street for a disturbance at 5:42 p.m. Monday night.
Officers now have a perimeter set up around the home and are working to get the suspect to come out.
It’s unclear whether anyone else is inside the home with the suspect.
The home is located just blocks away from San Jose State University.

The properties involved are a surface parking lot, site of the now-shuttered Lido nightclub, and the Knox-Goodrich building.
Urban Catalyst intends to construct a six-story office building that would use the existing Knox-Goodrich entry for the modern building.
If the final approvals occur as hoped, Urban Catalyst believes it can begin construction sometime in the first quarter of 2021.

title: 2 Found Dead in Car That Crashed Off of Highway 101 in San Jose
summary:
Two people were found dead Monday morning in a vehicle that had crashed off of northbound U.S. Highway 101 in San Jose, a California Highway Patrol spokesman said.
The crash was reported shortly before 8:20 a.m. off of the right-hand shoulder of northbound Highway 101 near McKee Road but may have happened sometime overnight, CHP Officer Ross Lee said.
Officers responded and found a 22-year-old woman behind the wheel and a 26-year-old man in a passenger seat of a car that had crashed into trees and bushes.
Both were pronounced dead, Lee said.
Lee said because no one reported witnessing the car going off the road, the time and cause of the crash have not been determined and remain under investigation.

Officers were called to Oak Grove High on Blossom Hill Road shortly before 11:30 a.m. for a report of a suspicious device, according to San Jose police Officer Gina Tepoorten.
A school gardener first discovered the device on the ground in the student parking lot, Tepoorten said.
Officials determined that the device was an “improvised explosive device,” Tepoorten said, or a homemade bomb.
In a message from East Side Union High School District Superintendent Chris D. Funk late Tuesday, the district thanked staff and students for their “professionalism, patience, and trust” during the lockdown.

summary:
Starting in 2014 and through at least 2017, postal workers were told that they had to finish routes within their allotted eight-hour shifts or receive discipline from management, alleged the workers’ union, the National Association of Letter Carriers.
Even so, supervisors across San Jose’s 12 stations regularly changed workers’ timecards when workers couldn’t make it back in time, the arbitrator found.
A Cambrian Park worker, for instance, was told not to use his real-time clock when he returned from the street, union officials told the arbitrator.
But throughout the arbitration process, the service provided no real rebuttal for the timecard records, the arbitrator wrote.
Throughout those years, the union told the arbitrator, management enjoyed high performance reviews.

The decade that just ended was one of change in the Bay Area.
That year, the population in the five-county Bay Area increased 1.45 percent, the fastest growth since 2000, according to the California Department of Finance.
In 2012, roughly 50,300 more people moved in than out of the Bay Area.
Everything goes upThe Bay Area is home to four of the five California counties with the fastest growth in median income from 2010 to 2018.
Big demographic shifts continueAsian-Americans became the largest racial group in two Bay Area counties — Alameda and Santa Clara — during the past decade.

title: San Jose Police: Driver Leaves Scene, His Passenger Dies In 3-Car Hit-And-Run Crash

SAN JOSE (CBS SF) – At least one person has died following a three-vehicle, hit-and-run traffic collision in East San Jose on Tuesday night, according to police.
The collision was first reported at 10:12 p.m. at the intersection of Alum Rock and Jackson avenues, Officer Gina Tepoorten said.
Tepoorten said a 1999 Honda sedan traveling eastbound on Alum Rock Avenue hit a 2016 Tesla going northbound on Jackson Avenue.
The Honda then veered into the westbound lanes of Alum Rock and hit a 2019 Dodge Durango.
According to Tepoorten, two male passengers in the Honda needed to be extricated by San Jose Fire Department crews.

The 340-unit Terra House apartment complex, previously known as Avana Skyway, was bought Nov. 18, according to documents on file with Santa Clara County officials.
TREA Terra House, a Chicago-based affiliate of Teachers Insurance and Annuity, paid $145.2 million in cash for the apartments, the county property records show.

title: Google Has Banned Zoom From Employees in Light of 'Security Vulnerabilities'

The story began last week when Google emailed its employees whose work laptops used Zoom, warning employees of "security vulnerabilities" and hinted that the videoconferencing software would cease to function on employee laptops sometime this week.
Last month, roughly 200 million people used Zoom every day, compared to only 10 million in December 2019.

title: Homelessness rose 2.7% in 2019, driven by a surge in California, HUD says
summary:
The homeless population in the US increased 2.7% this year largely because of a surge in unsheltered and chronically homeless individuals in California, the US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) said in a news release Friday.
The study found that 567,715 people across the nation experienced homelessness on a single night in 2019, an increase of 14,885 people compared with 2018.
The number of people experiencing homelessness dropped in 29 states and Washington, DC in 2019, the news release said.
But the rise in homelessness in California and elsewhere on the West Coast “offset” the nationwide decreases, the office said.
“In fact, homelessness in California is at a crisis level and needs to be addressed by local and state leaders with crisis-like urgency.”An additional 21,306 people were homeless in California in 2019, up 16.4% from the previous year, HUD said.

summary:
It may not be a white Christmas in the Bay Area, but for many, it could be a wet one.
While the region is set to get a break from rain on Monday and Tuesday after a wet weekend, forecasters say a new storm system will be coming to town by Tuesday evening and into Christmas morning, albeit a weak one.
“That system right now does not look to be a big rainmaker,” Roger Gass, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service said Sunday.
However, Sunday night into Monday, look for widespread lows in the mid-30s for inland East Bay valleys, and 40s around the Bay, Gass said.
Monday night into Tuesday morning may be one of the colder nights, with San Jose and inland South Bay places hovering in the upper 30s.

Taxi San Jose, a nonprofit started by independent taxi drivers and small company operators over what they considered unfair working conditions forced on drivers at other companies, has provided the on-demand dispatch services at the airport since 2005.

Unlike a bond measure, the funds raised from the new transfer tax would flow into the city’s general fund, and officials could not legally restrict the use of the money.
Khamis told his colleagues Tuesday afternoon that he would support the measure if it was placed on the ballot as a special tax rather than a general tax.
“It makes it sound like we’re going to spend all of this money on housing veterans and homeless people, but this is a general tax,” he said.
The tax would vary based on a property’s transfer value — $3.75 per $500 for $2 million-$5 million properties, $5 per $500 for $5 million-$10 million properties and $7.50 per $500 for properties worth more than $10 million.
For the affected properties, the new tax would be placed on top of the city’s current property transfer tax, which is applied to properties at a rate of $3.30 per $1,000.

After years of complaints from San Jose residents and threats of lawsuits from city officials over the nuisance, blight and homeless encampments along the Union Pacific tracks, the railroad operator is finally doing something about it.
For the first time in years, Union Pacific has launched an extensive, citywide cleanup and abatement effort along its San Jose tracks — affecting hundreds of homeless residents who have sought refuge in the somewhat secluded and undisturbed area amid the region’s deepening homelessness crisis.
The cleanup effort, which started last month and is expected to last until the end of the year, is just the first step toward what city officials hope will be a long-term solution to the tents and trash that have long lined the tracks.

title: Atmospheric river to hit Bay Area early Sunday, followed by Christmas Eve storm
summary:
Bay Area residents should gear up for a week of travel delays and possible flooding, with the tail end of an atmospheric river slated to hit Northern California this weekend, followed by a soggy, wind-whipped Christmas holiday.
And as the rain dries up in the Bay Area Sunday night, the Pineapple Express will move southeast, bring rain — and the ensuing travel chaos — to Southern California Monday and Tuesday.
Christmas Day’s expected high is 52 degrees across San Jose, Oakland and San Francisco, and 48 degrees in Santa Rosa.
As usual, California Highway Patrol’s San Jose unit will send all available personnel out on the road to anticipate drunk driving on Christmas, Officer Ross Lee said Friday.
But this year, the agency is also bracing itself for bad driving conditions as a result of the holiday weather.

title: Gray days ahead for the Bay Area, but not much rain

She Is A Fan Of Almost Any Food That Is Fried
summary:
After storms that caused travel mayhem, road closures and rainbows last week, the Bay Area is now stuck in a kind of weather purgatory for days on end: Not much rain, but not much sun, either.
In the South Bay and East Bay, though, clouds will give way only to a few isolated sprinkles throughout the week.
Some light showers pitter-pattered in Oakland and other portions of the East Bay and some cities along the Peninsula overnight into Wednesday, but it started and stopped periodically.
A stronger downfall isn’t expected until Dec. 18, Canepa said, with a quarter-inch to half-inch predicted in inland cities in the South and East Bay and around double that expected in Bay Area mountains.
Highs will hover in the mid-50s on Monday across the South Bay, North Bay and East Bay before next week’s storm system arrives in earnest.

title: Bay Area weather: Dry skies to return but only briefly
authors: Jason Green Is A Breaking News Reporter For The Bay Area News Group. He Works Week Nights
Spends Most Of His Time Covering Crime
Public Safety. A Graduate Of Uc Santa Barbara
He Cut His Teeth At The Inland Valley Daily Bulletin
Has Been With The Bay Area News Group Since Its Inception.
summary:
Following a brief but mighty mid-week storm system, folks looking to travel to and from the Bay Area for the Christmas holiday will have a clear window between now and Saturday afternoon, according to the National Weather Service.
That window will close late Saturday afternoon, when another system arrives in the North Bay and makes its way southward, said Ryan Walbrun, a meteorologist with the weather service’s forecast office in Monterey.
“Friday through the first half of Saturday will be good in terms of dry roads,” he said.
Walbrun said the system will also bring snow to the Sierra Nevada on Saturday night and likely complicate travel.
Walbrun said another storm system is expected to reach the region by Christmas Eve.

title: Tombstones at San Jose City Hall remember homeless deaths
summary:
Tombstones stood in row after row at San Jose City Hall on a chilly Saturday afternoon.
The 161 tombstones represent the number of homeless deaths that occurred in Santa Clara County within the past 12 months, a somber reminder of the exacerbating housing crisis in the area.
Shaunn Cartwright, an advocate for the homeless, conceived the idea of tombstones as a stark visual reminder of those who died.
Homeless deaths dropped slightly to 138 in 2018, and 132 people were reported dead in 2016.
She sat in the audience, waiting for an opportunity to speak during the community forum about preventing homeless deaths on Saturday.

The Sunnyvale Department of Public Safety said 26-year-old Carlos Duran confronted the victim near the intersection of Columbia and Roosevelt avenues about 5:15 p.m. on Dec. 8.
Duran then got into a waiting vehicle and left the scene, according to the department.

Duran and Pedraza-Melgoza were booked into county jail on charges including attempted murder with criminal street gang enhancements, according to the department.
